Title: Coral not coal: Enlisting the worlds of fame and celebrity in climate change politics
Source title: 78th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management, AOM 2018
Abstract: As the physical manifestations of anthropogenic climate disruption have become increasingly evident, so political contestation has increased over how best to respond. These contestations become particularly pronounced where extreme climate-related weather events provide a specific focus for political debate. In this paper we focus on the case of a specificlimate hotspot; Australia's Great Barrier Reef and recent, extreme coral bleaching events. Using the conceptual framework of Boltanski and Thevenot's (2006) economies of worth, we explore how appeals to fame and celebrity have proved central to the political dispute over how to respond to this climate disruption. Our paper contributes not only to debates over the celebritization of climate politics, but also to our understanding of the role of fame and celebrity as a source of political critique and justification. © 2018 Academy of Management. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Anthropogenic climate; Australia; Conceptual frameworks; Coral bleaching; Extreme climates; Great Barrier Reef; Political debates; Weather events; Climate change

Title: What is innovation anyway? The coevolution of innovation controls and deep organizational structures for innovation
Source title: 78th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management, AOM 2018
Abstract: Enabling innovation processes, constitutes one of the primary functions of organizational control in modern organizations. While studies show that control may indeed enable innovation, little is known about the process through which control mechanisms emerge, given the intention to enable innovation processes. This shortcoming is of crucial relevance, since control receives its enabling characteristics during the control creation and - implementation process. This paper elaborates theory on how organizational members assign meaning to control mechanisms and subsequently engage in the creation and modification of control mechanisms. In particular, we show how the interaction between deeply ingrained concertive control mechanisms, which is the shared conviction of innovation groups about what innovation is, with formal surface control mechanisms shape to which extent organizational members perceive formal controls to be congruent to their control needs. The need for particular controls emerges under conditions where organizational members experience incongruencies between formal surface controls and concertive deep controls. To mitigate these incongruencies, organizational members engage in practices aiming to calibrate formal controls to fit their control needs, and to drive the consolidation of concertive controls to safeguard the functioning of these formal controls. Our analysis shows that the way how an organization ends up to control its innovation process depends on the interaction between existing control mechanisms and the control elements it introduces to enable innovation. The theoretical framework builds on insights from a multi-year inductive field study of the transformation of an innovation process at a chemicals manufacturer. © 2018 Academy of Management. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Chemicals manufacturers; Control mechanism; Implementation process; Innovation process; Organizational controls; Organizational structures; Primary functions; Theoretical framework; Process control

Title: Human resource practices and coercive control interact to predict CWB: A meta-ethnographic study
Source title: 78th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management, AOM 2018
Abstract: Drawing on ideas from the resource based view of the firm, the notion of gift exchange, and efficiency wage theory, we examine the relationship between high- performance human resources practices (HPHRP) and employee counterproductive work behavior (CWB). We also examine whether HPHRP interact with coercive control systems to predict these outcomes. Using meta- ethnographic data collected from 149 organizational ethnographies, we found that HPHRP and coercive control interacted such that the negative association between HPHRP and CWB was buffered by coercive control. Further analysis indicates that this interaction remained even after controlling for the monetary rewards paid to employees, suggesting that the interactions we detected were largely driven by nonmonetary HPHRP as opposed to monetary HPHRP. © 2018 Academy of Management. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Counterproductive work behaviors; Efficiency wage theory; Ethnographic study; Gift exchanges; Human resource practices; Monetary rewards; Resource-based view of the firm; Personnel

Title: Unexpected entrepreneurs: Entrepreneurs with disabilities’ embodied identity struggles
Source title: 78th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management, AOM 2018
Abstract: This study investigates how entrepreneurs with physical disabilities deal, in their identity work, with the contradiction between a pervasive neoliberal discourse of the entrepreneur as an unencumbered individual and an equally pervasive discourse of disability precisely as an encumbered body. Drawing on in-depth interviews, four key discursive practices used by speakers to construct an entrepreneurial identity were identified: the archetypical entrepreneur, the unique entrepreneur, the collective entrepreneur, and the entrepreneur by default. Our results are broadly in line with the literature on the identity struggles of entrepreneurs belonging to historically subordinated social groups, such as older, female and ethnic minority entrepreneurs, confirming the key role played by a combination of discursive practices that assimilate the self to the dominant discourse of the entrepreneur and practices that make room for difference through the business case. At the same time, the analysis shows that in their identity work, speakers also undermine key tenets of the dominant neoliberal discourse of the entrepreneur in two ways. First, they reconstitute entrepreneurship as a collective endeavour, rather than an individual one, emphasizing interpersonal relations and mutual dependence. Second, they de-essentialize and demystify the discourse of the entrepreneurial self by constructing entrepreneurship as 'doing' without 'being', opening up room to acknowledge barriers and contingencies affecting the self and his or her entrepreneurial undertakings. These insights speak back to the literature on the neoliberal entrepreneurial self, providing glimpses of counter- discourses which have the potential of transforming dominant understandings of entrepreneurship. © 2018 Academy of Management. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Business case; Ethnic minorities; In-depth interviews; Interpersonal relations; Mutual dependences; Physical disability; Social groups; Two ways

Title: Life beyond emergence: Institutional intermediaries and the persistence of hybrid forms
Source title: 78th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management, AOM 2018
Abstract: We report on a population of public-private hybrid organizations. By bridging the literature on institutional complexity and hybrids with insights from imprinting, we illuminate the role of field-level institutional intermediaries who embed their prioritization of institutional logics in templates for organizing, and provide them to organizations during multiple sensitive periods. © 2018 Academy of Management. All rights reserved.

Title: When do specialists become entrepreneurs? The triggering effect of social network diversity
Source title: 78th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management, AOM 2018
Abstract: We argue that individuals with more specialized prior knowledge are more likely to become entrepreneurs when their social networks feature greater knowledge diversity. Evidence comes from an examination of 1,324 MBA students who were quasi-randomly assigned to small study groups, allowing us to observe exogenous variation in network knowledge diversity. © 2018 Academy of Management. All rights reserved.

Title: The impact of recruiter political skill and organization reputation on applicant attraction in the recruitment process
Source title: 78th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management, AOM 2018
Abstract: Researchers have identified various recruiter and organization characteristics that individually impact recruitment effectiveness. The present study examined applicants' attraction to organizations based on political skill of the recruiter and the reputation of the organization. Results from a 2 x 2 experimental (N = 576) study hypothesized, and found support for, the interaction between recruiter political skill and organization reputation, demonstrating that applicants' attraction to organizations increases as organization reputation increases for recruiters high in political skill, but not for recruiters low in political skill. Contributions of these results to theory and research, strengths and limitations, directions for future research, and practical implications are discussed. © 2018 Academy of Management. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Political skills; Recruitment process

Title: The impact of dynamic capabilities on sme sustainable performance
Source title: 78th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management, AOM 2018
Abstract: This paper addresses the debate on the ability/inability of SMEs to balance social, environmental and economic objectives by integrating insights from the dynamic capabilities literature. Using unique survey data from 297 Dutch SMEs, we propose that integrative dynamic capabilities simultaneously drive all three pillars of sustainability in SMEs. © 2018 Academy of Management. All rights reserved.

Title: 78th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management, AOM 2018
Source title: 78th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management, AOM 2018
Abstract: The proceedings contain 269 papers. The topics discussed include: fast and rigorous: configurational determinants of strategic decision-making balance; intercultural communication challenges in east-east encounters; beyond the tipping point: the curvilinear relationships between transformational leadership, leader-member exchange, and emotional exhaustion; multi-layer governance in platform ecosystems of established companies; not only a matter of dynamic managerial capabilities: making more of corporate resources in dynamic environments; taking leaps of faith: evaluation criteria and resource commitments for breakthrough inventions; the role of interacting diversities and the location of faultlines in inter-organizational teams; creative self-efficacy and creative performance: understanding the underlying mechanisms; the double-edged sword effect of team proactive personality on team performance: political skill helps read the wind; examining how leader character strengths and ethical leadership relate to leader outcomes; from the ground up: gender, space, and self-employment in a Colombian housing project; and institutional voids and the emancipatory potential of digital entrepreneurship: evidence from Saudi Arabia.

Title: Complementor strategies in smartphone application markets
Source title: 78th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management, AOM 2018
Abstract: A large and increasing share of global economic activity takes place in ecosystems organized around platforms through which distinct groups conduct transactions. Smartphone application (app) markets are an increasingly important example, offering software developers a large, heterogeneous installed base of users as potential customers and low barriers to entry. However, these low barriers to entry result in intense competition for user attention, downloads, and revenues, while the appropriability regime is generally weak. In platform ecosystem settings such as this, how do producers of complementary goods and services (complementors) seek to compete, and which strategies are effective? To explore these questions, I collected rich qualitative data on 44 apps created for the Windows Phone store during their development period, as well as objective, quantitative measures of their performance post-release. The results of a qualitative comparative analysis of the cases show that developers choose to compete on combinations of novelty, execution, and owned or accessed (third-party) complementary assets, and suggest that developers over-estimate the advantages of the latter two options. These findings raise questions about what kinds of specialized complementary assets and demand-size strategies can be the basis for competition in platform ecosystems of this kind. © 2018 Academy of Management. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Application programs; Commerce; Competition; Smartphones; Appropriability regimes; Complementary assets; Complementary goods; Global economic activity; Platform ecosystems; Qualitative comparative analysis; Quantitative measures; Smart-phone applications; Ecosystems

Title: Cultural entrepreneurship: Towards a theory of meaning cultivation
Source title: 78th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management, AOM 2018
Abstract: Culture is critical for organizational and entrepreneurial outcomes, and the notion of cultural entrepreneurship is increasingly gaining currency for shedding light on the ways actors rally support for new ideas or products, or break new ground at the collective level of an industry or a market category. Despite the broad potential of cultural entrepreneurship, however, current understandings undertheorize the role that culture plays in the process, remain confined to the study of new venture legitimation and resource acquisition, or narrowly emphasize storytelling over other cultural mechanisms. Addressing these shortcomings, this paper builds an overarching framework of cultural entrepreneurship. First, we squarely put culture in cultural entrepreneurship and recast the notion as a process of meaning cultivation. We then take cultural entrepreneurship beyond entrepreneurship by delineating its conceptual boundaries in a way that is not empirically grounded but theoretically driven. Finally, beside storytelling, we advocate for a richer understanding of the cultural vehicles by which new meanings are cultivated. In sum, our central contribution is to broaden our understanding of what cultural entrepreneurship is, where it occurs, and by which means. © 2018 Academy of Management. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: New ventures; Resource acquisition; Shedding light; Theory of meanings

Title: Executives’ network change and their promotability during a merger
Source title: 78th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management, AOM 2018
Abstract: Previous research suggests that large, open personal networks with many structural holes help executives’ career, focusing on stable organizations. Using pre- and post-merger email networks, however, we find that building closed networks can be more advantageous if they are created across organizational boundaries (legacy organizational and functional) during a merger. © 2018 Academy of Management. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Merging; E-mail networks; Organizational boundaries; Personal networks; Structural holes; Mergers and acquisitions

Title: Do early birds help and voice more? It all depends on supervisor pacing style
Source title: 78th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management, AOM 2018
Abstract: Drawing on the social entrainment perspective, this study examines the relationship between employee'supervisor pacing fit and employee task performance and helping and voice behaviors. The polynomial regression analyses and response surface tests conducted for 235 employee'supervisor dyads generally supported the proposed fit effect for helping and voice behaviors. Employee helping behavior was higher when both employees and supervisors exhibited an early action pacing style and when both adopted a deadline action pacing style than when there was a misfit. Similarly, employees engaged in more voice behavior when their pacing style matched that of their supervisor than when there was a mismatch. Contrary to our prediction, we detected the main effect of employee pacing style on task performance, such that task performance was higher for employees with an early action pacing style than for those with a deadline action pacing style. Such a differential effect of pacing fit provides a nuanced understanding of the roles of pacing style and alignment in work outcomes. © 2018 Academy of Management. All rights reserved.

Title: Too much of a good thing? The nonlinear effect of dynamic capabilities on new venture survival
Source title: 78th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management, AOM 2018
Abstract: This research conceptualizes and then shows how one type of dynamic capability - network capability - does not always have a positive relationship with the survival of new technology-based ventures. Using data from a survey of 280 new ventures combined with secondary and patent data, we show that although network capability is beneficial at low to intermediate levels, it decreases new venture survival at high levels. The influence of network capability on survival also decreases under conditions of high environmental hostility but no moderation effect is found for environmental dynamism. Our results suggest that investment in dynamic capabilities in new ventures should be optimized, not maximized, for survival. Also, environmental hostility is more relevant than dynamism for entrepreneurs in new ventures to monitor. © 2018 Academy of Management. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Dynamic capabilities; Environmental dynamisms; Environmental hostility; Intermediate level; Network capability; New technologies; Nonlinear effect; Patent datum; Enterprise resource management

Title: Understanding the link between governance and performance in charities
Source title: 78th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management, AOM 2018
Abstract: Although the relationship between governance and performance has been the focus of scholarly work for decades, most of this research has studied for-profit organizations. In contrast, the governance of nonprofit organizations have received very little attention. Therefore, our paper examines whether the governance choices implemented by a large sample of charities are linked to their performance. Charities afford a fertile context to further understand the impact of governance and agency related problems, since unlike their for-profit counterparts, they do not face mandatory governance practices. Our sample encompasses a total of $70 billion in donations across 6,741 U.S.-based charities. The findings demonstrate governance has a positive impact on charitable organizations. Specifically, the results of our study indicate that common governance practices - such as independent boards, CEO oversight, and transparency enhance the degree to which charitable contributions are allocated toward the mission of these organizations. Overall, we find that despite the often- assumed altruistic orientation of charitable organizations, governance practices can play a critical role in these settings. Our study has important implications for agency theory, corporate governance and the broader application of for-profit logic in nonprofit settings. © 2018 Academy of Management. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Agency theory; Corporate governance; Non profit organizations; Positive impacts; Scholarly works; Profitability

Title: How product quality and affinity toward the firm influence reputation for quality
Source title: 78th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management, AOM 2018
Abstract: Despite substantial reputation research, we know little about reputation’s formation or its interaction with related constructs. We use two experiments to examine how comparisons of two firms’ affinities and product qualities influence observers’ perceptions of reputation for quality. © 2018 Academy of Management. All rights reserved.

Title: Developers’ progression from periphery to core in the linux kernel development project
Source title: 78th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management, AOM 2018
Abstract: To coordinate activities between developers, open source software (OSS) communities assign roles of lateral authority to some developers. Prior research has mainly described the characteristics of and functional roles within these virtual organizations, but few have examined which community members take on roles of lateral authority, or investigated what drives the progression of developers from peripheral roles to core roles. We develop and test a theoretical framework, which explains developers' pace of progression from periphery to core through technical contributions and communication activity. Our approach differs from prior research by highlighting the moderating role of developers' focus regarding their community engagement. Using unique longitudinal data from the Linux kernel development project, our results suggest that the positive influence of technical contributions is negatively moderated when developers make broad, rather than focused, contributions to different subsystems. Conversely, the positive effect of communication activity is amplified the more developers engage in conversations on different topics and the more they respond to the queries of other community members. Our findings contribute to research on lateral governance in OSS communities, and to the more general debate on the benefits of specialization. © 2018 Academy of Management. All rights reserved.

Title: Exploring women’s work-life narratives in search of authentic selves
Source title: 78th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management, AOM 2018
Abstract: The paper extends the critical debates on authenticity and organizations through exploring the discourses of authentic femininity, entangled with the discourses of ‘postfeminism’. This discursive entanglement, I argue, discredits the necessity of organizational change towards gender equality, and contributes to a reversal of feminist achievements in organizations. © 2018 Academy of Management. All rights reserved.

Title: The effect of acquisitions on customers: Twitter evidence from the Dollar tree-Family Dollar acquisition
Source title: 78th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management, AOM 2018
Abstract: Mergers and acquisitions are important for growth. The literature has studied extensively disruption to internal stakeholders but mostly overlooked that to customers, who are essential for growth. We study the effect of M&A on customers by applying a synthetic control approach to the Dollar Tree’s acquisition of Family Dollar. © 2018 Academy of Management. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Forestry; Sales; Synthetic control; Mergers and acquisitions

Title: Iterative coordination in search
Source title: 78th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management, AOM 2018
Abstract: Despite their widespread use in product development and entrepreneurship practice, the influence of highly iterative project management frameworks on organizational search remains largely understudied in the strategy and innovation literatures. With a leading software development firm, we embed a field experiment within a one-day software app development hackathon to measure the effects of rapid iteration on new product search outcomes. We find that firms that iterate more frequently are more productive overall in their holistic search effort, but must face fundamental trade-offs between pursuing exploitative search and exploratory search. While rapidly iterating firms were more likely to sample distant neighborhoods on their search landscape, they ultimately invested in exploitative search at the expense of exploratory search. Our study offers a critical test of the popular project management framework, Agile software development, and places caveats on its professed link to innovation. Our findings contribute to the literatures on organizational search and the microfoundations of strategy making in entrepreneurial settings. Methodologically, we offer novel contributions to the strategy literature by instrumenting for search using industry leading version control software, Git. © 2018 Academy of Management. All rights reserved.

Title: Shaping top managers' moods: Board emotion regulation in the strategy-formulation process
Source title: 78th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management, AOM 2018
Abstract: We studied a company that formulated a radically new strategy as it faced extreme performance pressures. We found that the company's top managers strategy formulation was aided by the board of directors affective actions. The board regulated top managers emotions, which helped the top managers to envision more strategic options and evaluate them more comprehensively. Our research enriches a dominantly cold cognitive view of strategy formulation by showing how various kinds of emotion regulation practices could benefit the strategy formulation process at different stages. © 2018 Academy of Management. All rights reserved.

Title: Scientific breakthroughs and patent scope: The impact of the human genome project on early stage drug patents
Source title: 78th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management, AOM 2018
Abstract: How scientific maps influence technological search and innovation is not well understood. In this study, we analyze the impact of the human genome, a detailed scientific map, on drug discovery. In the drug industry, deep understanding of disease is essential for designing new therapeutics. Two mechanisms are explored by which scientific maps influence technological search: 1) predictive power and precision of the map can alter existing search strategies and novelty of outcomes 2) public nature of the map can attract new entrants, leading to more competition and stronger efforts to protect intellectual property. Analyses reveal a sharp increase in small-molecule drug patenting and patented compounds coinciding with the public release of gene sequences. Using a difference-in-differences estimation we find that the availability of the human genome is an exogenous shock that increases novel compound production across the industry by 64%, controlling for new tools like combinatorial chemistry. Together, these reveal an interesting finding' open access scientific maps not only increase the rate and technological novelty of invention, but also spur industry competition suggesting that publicly-funded science like the human genome can enhance both quantity and quality of industry innovation. © 2018 Academy of Management. All rights reserved.

Title: Inflated accounts: Institutional posturing by legitimacy-constrained regulators
Source title: 78th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management, AOM 2018
Abstract: Much work has shown how regulators can trigger organizational and institutional change. However, regulators themselves are also dynamic institutions, and we know little about how they evolve, especially in response to shocks. This study highlights the dynamic processes through which private regulatory bodies change along with the field. © 2018 Academy of Management. All rights reserved.

Title: Cueing morality: Are all moral foundations recognized equally by shareholders?
Source title: 78th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management, AOM 2018
Abstract: Markets are particularly sensitive to the quarterly earnings releases of publicly-traded firm, and tend to react negatively to earnings surprises, as they are indicative of increases in income stream uncertainty. Post-earnings announcement conference calls are a useful tool capable of mitigating shareholders negative reactions to earnings surprises, as they provide top managers with an ideal environment for the release new rhetorical cues capable of reassuring the market and triggering new buy decisions. This paper investigates whether cues of morality can mitigate stock sell-offs in the face of earnings uncertainty, and draws on Moral Foundations Theory to study the effect of universal moral cues (Harm/Care and Fairness/Reciprocity rhetoric) and primarily conservative moral cues (Ingroup/Loyalty, Authority/Respect and Purity/Sanctity rhetoric) on market performance. The study relies on a longitudinal dataset of 1,920 firm-quarter observations corresponding to calls held by firms listed on the S&P 500 in 2015, and relies on Computer-Assisted-Text-Analysis (CATA) and event-study methodology to test hypotheses. The results suggest that cues of universal moral foundations have a strong mitigating effect on stock sell-offs, and are able to create firm value; while cues primarily conservative moral foundations are not found to have an effect on market performance. A discussion of the findings and their implications for research and practice concludes the study. © 2018 Academy of Management. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Commerce; Computer aided analysis; Earnings; Shareholders; Statistical tests; Computer assisted; Earnings surprise; Event studies; Firm value; Market performance; Mitigating effects; Text analysis; Top managers; Foundations

Title: I’ve got you under my skin: Relational identity work in situated workplace interactions
Source title: 78th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management, AOM 2018
Abstract: While identity is commonly believed to be shaped through relations, most organizational research into identity directs attention toward individuals' constructions of a coherent en distinct sense of self and away from the situated construction of 'self' and 'other' in workplace interactions. This leaves unexplored the identity work that is done when relations itself are equivocal and changing. Building on a few studies that delved into the interpersonal and situational dimensions of identity work, we address the question how actors mutually position themselves vis-vis others in interactional dynamics. Our ethnographic analysis of everyday encounters between nurses, residents and relatives in a Dutch nursing home, shows how 'relational identity work' is performed through 'self-other matching' (mutually re-affirming), 'self-other mismatching' (mutually negating) and 'shifting' between different identity patterns. Subsequently, we analyze complications of relational identity work as a third actor enters the stage and mixes up the dynamics of workplace relations. Clarifying how organizational actors shape a flexible sense of self vis-vis multiple others, our exploration opens up the field of identity studies for analyzing interactional dynamics of workplace relations. In doing so, we explain how relational identity work between multiple actors impacts the formation of partnerships in- and around organizations when the configuration of relations is changing. © 2018 Academy of Management. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Nursing; Multiple actors; Nursing homes; Organizational actors; Organizational research; Dynamics

Title: Further unpacking creativity with a problem-space theory of creativity and constraint
Source title: 78th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management, AOM 2018
Abstract: Scholars have “unpacked creativity” by identifying two dimensions that—when combined—give rise to different types of creativity (Unsworth, 2001). I build on this research by further unpacking creativity with a third dimension of creativity, which creates different confluences of constraint that can predict positive or negative effects on creativity. © 2018 Academy of Management. All rights reserved.

Title: Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde: How do academic entrepreneurs deal with identity conflict?
Source title: 78th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management, AOM 2018
Abstract: Academic entrepreneurs are always faced with an identity conflict. Integrating identity theory with social identity theory, we investigate the tension of duality between scholar identity and entrepreneur identity. We contend that there is an inverted U-shaped relationship between social identity continuity and identity conflict, and another inverted U-shaped relationship between multiple identity experiences and identity conflict. Furthermore, we conclude that identity conflict may hurt academic entrepreneurship performance. Our hypotheses are largely supported based on a survey of 256 academic entrepreneurs in China. © 2018 Academy of Management. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Academic entrepreneurship; Multiple identities; Social identity; Social identity theories; U-shaped

Title: The role of interacting diversities and the location of faultlines in inter-organizational teams
Source title: 78th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management, AOM 2018
Abstract: Inter-organizational collaboration through joint teams with members from multiple organizations has become an organizational reality. As research has shown team composition to be a predictor of team performance, informed staffing of such teams based on team members' demographics seems promising. However, mixed and inconclusive findings regarding how team diversity affects team performance accentuate the need for simultaneously considering multiple diversity attributes, as emphasized by the literature on faultlines. We therefore theorize that organizational diversity in inter-organizational teams becomes a liability when the team members are diverse on another attribute (i.e., age), and that performance effects of resulting diversity faultlines are contingent upon their location within the team. We test our hypotheses with archival sports data of 7,514 individuals from 336 national soccer teams at fourteen FIFA World Cups. Our results show that, with increasing levels of age diversity, the positive performance effect of organizational diversity is reversed. Moreover, abandoning the assumption that team members equally contribute to their teams' performance, faultline strength turned out to be beneficial for team performance when the faultline separated the core team members from the peripheral ones, whereas faultline strength impeded team performance when the faultline existed within the core team. We discuss resulting implications for theory development on inter-organizational teams. © 2018 Academy of Management. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Inter-organizational; Interorganizational collaboration; Multiple organizations; Organizational diversity; Performance effect; Team composition; Team performance; Theory development; Sports

Title: Getting ahead by staying put? Specialization and social capital in U.S. civil service careers
Source title: 78th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management, AOM 2018
Abstract: This empirical paper shows that generalists are compensated at higher salary levels than specialists, defined by the number of occupations held, in the US federal civil service over the period from 1989 to 2011. Meaningful positive returns to occupational generalization occur only beyond the fifth year of employment. One potential explanation of this generalist advantage—the role of generalists as coordinators—is tested. Findings are consistent with a model of capabilities and coordination, though future research will need to consider other important factors, especially social capital development over the career. © 2018 Academy of Management. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Compensation (personnel); Civil service; Social capitals; Law enforcement

Title: Cultural transmission & variation in organizational populations: A formal model
Source title: 78th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management, AOM 2018
Abstract: This paper develops an agent-based model to explain cultural diversity in organizational populations as a function of inter- and intra-firm cultural transmission. Bridging firm processes with labor market mechanisms, the model conceptualizes individual employees as ‘cultural carriers’ and provides a basis for the study of inter-organizational cultural processes. © 2018 Academy of Management. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Computational methods; Agent-based model; Cultural diversity; Cultural transmission; Firm process; Formal model; Inter-organizational; Labor markets; Autonomous agents

Title: Understanding the conditions for environmental legitimacy: A configurational approach
Source title: 78th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management, AOM 2018
Abstract: Prior research on environmental legitimacy has significantly advanced our understanding of how single factors affect stakeholders assessment of the environmental legitimacy of a particular firm. Given that stakeholders build their perception holistically on a combination of multiple, interdependent factors, we investigate how different, complex configurations of factors could lead to positive or negative legitimacy evaluations from stakeholders. Based on our fsQCA methodology, we find that none of the conditions we identified is either sufficient or necessary to achieve environmental legitimacy. More specifically, results indicate that (a) that environmental performance and legitimacy are not necessarily associated in a one-to-one relationship; (b) that the combination of internal adaptation and impression management initiatives might be less effective in generating legitimacy than expected; and (c) that global and local strategies can both lead to high legitimacy when appropriately complemented. © 2018 Academy of Management. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Complex configuration; Environmental performance; Impression management; Local strategies; Environmental management

Title: Asymmetric regulation, managerial discretion, and corporate political strategies
Source title: 78th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management, AOM 2018
Abstract: We study why managers engage in corporate political strategizing. Our rigorous data driven historical study of top management strategizing, of a state-owned telecommunications provider for a period of 18 years, exposes previously unattended links between top management’s managerial discretion and engagement in political strategizing. We find two managerial discretion dilemmas triggering political strategizing during market convergence: (1) resource discretion due to asymmetric regulation; and (2) market discretion due to unbalanced competitive preconditions. We contribute with a novel understanding of the contextual and managerial antecedents of political strategizing, and a dynamic view on managerial discretion. Furthermore, we advance a rigorous digital history approach, one that is historically cognizant and temporally and contextually grounded, to study top management strategizing. © 2018 Academy of Management. All rights reserved.

Title: Deep received cosmologies during sensemaking: A mixed-method study of the 2008 Sichuan earthquake
Source title: 78th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management, AOM 2018
Abstract: As scholars continue to seek ways to break through the thickening membrane that separates academics from executives, funding organizations such as The Templeton Foundation are championing alternative methods of scholarly writing – seeking to upgrade scholars’ capacity to communicate with executives in position to reduce suffering in the world. For example, Karl Weick and Kathleen Sutcliffe (2015) have influenced a generation of international executives seeking to prevent cosmology episodes in the workplace. Following their lead, other management scholars are engaged in attempts to resolve a set of global “grand challenges” (e.g. de Rond & Lok, 2016; Kim & Davis, 2016; and Luo, Zhang, & Marquis, 2016). In this article, similarly, we focus on a specific component in the anatomy of cosmology episodes (anticipating, sense-losing, improvising, sense-remaking, renewing); more specifically, we address the role of deep cosmologies in the anticipating processes before a nation, community, organization, team, or individual is aware that they have entered into a cosmology episode. We juxtapose two complementary data sets – seeking primarily to communicate evidence-based research on the strategic management of cosmology episodes to leaders of humanitarian aid organizations. The first data set is a group of 138 sensemaking episodes drawn from a valuable census of management research articles published within the arena of “extreme context research” (Hallgren, Rouleau, & de Rond, in press), with a primary focus on sensemaking episodes published in Organization Studies. The second data set is our field notes from teaching the psychology of religion and disasters at Renmin University in Beijing, China, in a two-week course in July 2013 and a a four-week course in July 2014. Fusing these two data sets is an attempt to expand on Weick’s (2006) assertion that “Faith and belief are prerequisites to organizing and sensemaking” and to elaborate on Weick’s differentiation between faith (as “deep cosmologies”) from beliefs (as “shallow cognitions”). © 2018 Academy of Management. Title: How do leaders construct their purpose?
Source title: 78th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management, AOM 2018
Abstract: This article examines the underlying conditions of higher-order purpose leadership through an interview-based qualitative analysis of twelve entrepreneurs, whose commercial organisations are working to alleviate poverty in developing nations. MacIntyre (1981) argued that essential to telos-guided leadership is the development of virtues, practices and goods. This article finds that the salient virtues of higher-order purposeful leadership are humility, gratitude and justice, which involve the subjugation of the entrepreneurs self to the needs of others. Pertinent practices are identified as clarity of direction and more equitable resource allocation, which emerged from leaders expanded sense of connectedness. Goods produced involve significant systemic change and mutual transcendence, guided by a deep ecological awareness that goes beyond duality and short- term goals. This article highlights the need to include a concern for others into our understanding of leadership. © 2018 Academy of Management. All rights reserved.

Title: Does moral capital be an asset when there is a negative CSR event? Reexamining CSR buffering effect
Source title: 78th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management, AOM 2018
Abstract: This study investigates the valuation effects and the performance of the corporate social responsibility (CSR) activities adopted by the 72 CSR-awarded and the 87 non-awarded listed firms in Taiwan, using 1,368 positive and negative CSR events during the period of the 2008-2011 financial crisis. This study categorizes CSR activities into four groups'Xsociety, the environment, employee, and consumers' Xand provides an overview and a comparison of CSR activities in an emerging economy in Asia. This study focuses on the reputation effect for negative CSR events and compares the performance of the CSR-awarded and non-awarded firms for negative CSR activities. The results show that, in Taiwan, positive CSR activities are accompanied by a significant amount of positive stock price reactions and better long-term performance, which is consistent with the evidence found in the literature. However, compared with non-awarded firms, when CSR-awarded firms experience negative CSR events, their investors will impose stricter punishments. Consequently, the short- and long-term performances of CSR-awarded firms are inferior to those of non-awarded firms. © 2018 Academy of Management. All rights reserved.

Title: Challenge stressors and creativity: Moderating effect of emotional intelligence

Title: Maintaining morale during organizational change in the growing entrepreneurial firm
Source title: 78th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management, AOM 2018
Abstract: The transition from a founder-led start-up to a professionally managed firm entails significant change in the firms organizational design. Title: The impact of open innovation on employee mobility and entrepreneurship

Abstract: Prior research shows that firms can increase innovation performance by leveraging external sources of knowledge. Title: Employee incentives in microfinance institutions: Examining the importance of diversification and profit status
Source title: 78th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management, AOM 2018
Abstract: Non-profits across the economy are being pressured to take on the human resource management practices of for-profits, including the use of pay-for- performance. However, the use of pay-for-performance and competitive salaries is often thought to conflict with the non-profit business model, due to multidimensional organizational objectives and the effect of monetary incentives on intrinsically motivated employees. In this paper, I argue that performance-based pay can actually be effective if non-profit employees are driven by both the intrinsic value of the mission and a relational contract with the firm, wherein performance-based pay serves as a signal of organizational mission, rather than an effort-inducing financial incentive. The context of this paper is the microfinance industry, with data that includes observations on both for-profit and non-profit firms and variables that capture both financial and social goals. This data allows me to examine the ways in which non-profits utilize employee incentives and how they compare with for-profits in the same industry. I find that non-profit organizations, on average, pay employees less and utilize a lower level of performance-based pay. Further, non-profit organizations that make smaller loans reward employees on more dimensions than other microfinance firms. Even controlling for the products and services that firms offer, some differences in employee compensation between for-profit and non-profit organizations remain. This result suggests that neither the explanation of intrinsic motivation of employees nor the distinct products and services offered completely explains the different salary structures in non-profit organizations; rather different incentive dimensions may be used to signal the non-profits goals. © 2018 Academy of Management.
